ygData.subject: Re: [neat] New Paper on Combining Interactive Evolution with Novelty Search

Subject: Re: [neat] New Paper on Combining Interactive Evolution with Novelty Search
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=464818732; y=GrLQSQk5bD915qtq7rpyDI3m-Z9KS-zQIm8a2cw8Taf6iJ5BUHya
X-Yahoo-Profile: jeffreyclune
From: Jeff Clune <jclune@...>


--Apple-Mail=_32CBDB03-5539-4473-A5FE-0E1C3A3668E6
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=windows-1252

Hello Ken and Brian,

Congrats on your nice paper, especially for being nom=
inated for a Best Paper award. That=92s great!

I love the paper in general=
. I also have a question about one specific result that I find quite intere=
sting. Actually, it=92s something that I=92ve noticed in previous NS papers=
, but it really jumped out at me in your paper. As such, Joel also may have=
 thoughts on the subject. 

Figure 7 is fascinating to me. The first thing =
that jumps out (which I=92ve noticed in previous NS papers), is that there =
are very few points in the upper right corner of the hard map for the Novel=
ty Search treatment (by =93upper right corner I=92m including the thin hall=
way that leads to the open, upper-right corner). Similarly, there are few p=
oints in the intermediate chambers of the Medium map for the NS treatment (=
I=92ll focus on the hard map the rest of this email, but all of the observa=
tions apply to the medium map too). Those non-well-tread areas suggests a h=
uge nonlinearity in exploratory skills: my hypothesis is that the search pr=
ocess searches for a long while and then, boom, it suddenly produces a robo=
t with the right skill set and then the problem is solved. One might expect=
 different from NS: one could expect it to slowly fill up the map. In fact,=
 this seeming nonlinearity is one reason that Roby Velez and I wanted to in=
vestigate whether NS does produce such general exploratory skills in the 20=
14 GECCO paper we posted recently (video: http://youtu.be/P-EqOBqjTyU   =97=
 pdf: http://goo.gl/Iv180r ).

If you watch videos of robots in the lineage=
 that produces the champion, do you see such a nonlinearity? Are there a se=
ries of robots that get just a bit further down the path and then, all of t=
he sudden, an amazing robot that happens to explore all the way to the goal=
? If not, what is the explanation for the scarcity of points? It seems a bi=
t weird that NS can produce a robot that goes all the way to the goal witho=
ut stopping at lots of intermediate points unless it really is good at some=
 general exploration skill such as wall-following, and it thus happens to w=
ander past the goal (at which point the stopping criterion kicks in). 

Int=
erestingly, the fitness treatment also has this paucity of points in the up=
per right-hand corner. That suggests that fitness is also producing these g=
eneral exploratory skills on par with NS, which is exactly what Roby and I =
found. So, if the NS robots do exhibit this nonlinear skill level-up, it se=
ems fitness does too. Do videos of the champ lineage show a nonlinearity he=
re too? 

Those questions could have been asked of the original NS papers. =
Specifically in light of the new data in this paper, it=92s also interestin=
g to note how the pattern changes for the other treatments. The directed tr=
eatment has a few more points, though it is not obviously more and could be=
 noise and not signal. But it=92s clear that IEC and NA-IEC are very differ=
ent. 

IEC had to inch its way toward a solution. One can empathize with th=
e pain the human subjects (eplex lab members and friends/family, I presume!=
) had to go through to get to a solution. Why do you think IEC was worse th=
an directed evolution in this regard? I can=92t think of a good explanation=
, and would be interested in your thoughts. One fun thing you could do with=
 this data set is test the evolvability of these genomes in the large maze =
from the paper Roby and I just put out (and other mazes): the prediction ac=
cording to the thesis that objective-driven evolution creates non-evolvable=
, brittle, overwrought genomes is that these genomes would not be very evol=
vable compared to the NS and Fitness genomes. 

The NA-IEC data is also int=
eresting. On the one hand, it=92s less pathological than IEC in that there =
are fewer points. But, as you mention, the humans did transition into objec=
tive-driven evaluators at corners: it seems they selected anything that tur=
ned the corner just a bit more, inching their way around the bend. If that=
=92s true, we should also expect these genomes to be less evolvable than th=
ose evolved by NS, Fitness, and even DirectedFitness. Why do you think NS d=
oesn=92t produce these corner bends, but NA-IEC does? Maybe it=92s because =
NA-IEC doesn=92t spend so much time spinning its wheels early before findin=
g that nonlinear level-up robot that can suddenly explore really well. 

Wh=
at do you think? It would be interesting to carry those experiments out, bu=
t even if that never happens I=92d enjoy hearing your thoughts and predicti=
ons on these subjects. 

Congrats again on the nice work!
 
Best regards,
J=
eff Clune

Assistant Professor
Computer Science
University of Wyoming
jeffc=
lune@...
jeffclune.com

On May 6, 2014, at 12:36 PM, kstanley@...=
s.edu wrote:

> Brian Woolley and I are pleased to announce our new GECCO p=
aper, "A Novel Human-Computer Collaboration: Combining Novelty Search with =
Interactive Evolution."  
> 
> http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/woolley_gecco=
14.pdf
> 
> This paper discloses some interesting results that show that in=
 the hard maze domain, a human in collaboration with novelty search (and an=
 objective optimization function) can actually do better than novelty searc=
h alone, fitness alone, human+objective optimization alone, and more.  By b=
etter I don't just mean in terms of number of evaluations, but even (surpri=
singly) in total clock time.  
> 
> The main insight is that humans and nov=
elty search (NS) are complementary forces.  NS does a great job of collecti=
ng potential stepping stones from the search space, but humans are extremel=
y sensitive to certain very delicate key features (that may be difficult to=
 formalize even in a behavior characterization).  Thus if NS does most of t=
he work but humans are allowed to interleave a few very critical key decisi=
ons, the collaboration makes a good team.  
> 
> I think of NS in this cont=
ext as a sort of substitute for all the other users on Picbreeder when you =
are instead alone by yourself with only a computer to help you.  Ideally, y=
ou'd have hundreds of people scavenging the search space and presenting you=
 with every interesting stepping stone that they can, but short of that, NS=
 can play a similar role.
> 
> One other aspect of this study that I think =
is particularly interesting is the insight that we do not necessarily "help=
" people simply by trying to figure out where they want to go and then auto=
mating the search towards that inferred objective.  I think a lot of people=
 have the intuition that it would be cool if interactive evolution could fi=
gure out the kinds of things you like and then sort of accelerate itself by=
 choosing the stuff you would have chosen, but much faster.  However, what =
this study shows is that we humans have a much more pressing problem than s=
imply wishing to be a faster version of ourselves - rather, we need to push=
ed out of our comfort zone from time to time to help us see the possibiliti=
es we never imagined.  Otherwise we, just like an objective search, may ten=
d to stagnate.  NS can provide that push.
> 
> Best,
> 
> ken
> 
> 


--Apple-Mail=_32CBDB03-5539-4473-A5FE-0E1C3A3668E6
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/html;
	charset=windows-1252

</div><div><br></div><div>Figure 7 is fascinating to me.=

he NS treatment (I=92ll focus on the hard map the rest of this email, but a=
ll of the observations apply to the medium map too). Those non-well-tread a=
reas suggests a huge nonlinearity in exploratory skills: my hypothesis is t=
hat the search process searches for a long while and then, boom, it suddenl=
y produces a robot with the right skill set and then the problem is solved.=

nd I wanted to investigate whether NS does produce such general exploratory=

r></div><div>If you watch videos of robots in the lineage that produces the=

t get just a bit further down the path and then, all of the sudden, an amaz=

the explanation for the scarcity of points? It seems a bit weird that NS ca=
n produce a robot that goes all the way to the goal without stopping at lot=
s of intermediate points unless it really is good at some general explorati=
on skill such as wall-following, and it thus happens to wander past the goa=
l (at which point the stopping criterion kicks in). </div><div><br></d=
iv><div>Interestingly, the fitness treatment also has this paucity of point=
s in the upper right-hand corner. That suggests that fitness is also produc=
ing these general exploratory skills on par with NS, which is exactly what =
Roby and I found. So, if the NS robots do exhibit this nonlinear skill leve=
l-up, it seems fitness does too. Do videos of the champ lineage show a nonl=
inearity here too? </div><div><br></div><div>Those questions could hav=
e been asked of the original NS papers. Specifically in light of the new da=
ta in this paper, it=92s also interesting to note how the pattern changes f=
or the other treatments. The directed treatment has a few more points, thou=
gh it is not obviously more and could be noise and not signal. But it=92s c=
lear that IEC and NA-IEC are very different. </div><div><br></div><div=
>IEC had to inch its way toward a solution. One can empathize with the pain=
 the human subjects (eplex lab members and friends/family, I presume!) had =
to go through to get to a solution. Why do you think IEC was worse than dir=
ected evolution in this regard? I can=92t think of a good explanation, and =
would be interested in your thoughts. One fun thing you could do with this =
data set is test the evolvability of these genomes in the large maze from t=
he paper Roby and I just put out (and other mazes): the prediction accordin=
g to the thesis that objective-driven evolution creates non-evolvable, brit=
tle, overwrought genomes is that these genomes would not be very evolvable =
compared to the NS and Fitness genomes. </div><div><br></div><div>The =
NA-IEC data is also interesting. On the one hand, it=92s less pathological =
than IEC in that there are fewer points. But, as you mention, the humans di=
d transition into objective-driven evaluators at corners: it seems they sel=
ected anything that turned the corner just a bit more, inching their way ar=
ound the bend. If that=92s true, we should also expect these genomes to be =
less evolvable than those evolved by NS, Fitness, and even DirectedFitness.=
 Why do you think NS doesn=92t produce these corner bends, but NA-IEC does?=
 Maybe it=92s because NA-IEC doesn=92t spend so much time spinning its whee=
ls early before finding that nonlinear level-up robot that can suddenly exp=
lore really well. </div><div><br></div><div>What do you think? It woul=
d be interesting to carry those experiments out, but even if that never hap=
pens I=92d enjoy hearing your thoughts and predictions on these subjects.&n=

<br><div><div>On May 6, 2014, at 12:36 PM, <a href=3D"mailto:kstanley@cs.=
utexas.edu">kstanley@...</a> wrote:</div><br class=3D"Apple-inter=
change-newline"><blockquote type=3D"cite">












 
<div style=3D"back=
ground-color: #fff;">
<span style=3D"display:none"> </span>



    <di=
v id=3D"ygrp-text"><p>Brian Woolley and I are pleased to announce our new G=
ECCO paper, "A Novel Human-Computer Collaboration: Combining Novelty Search=
 with Interactive Evolution."  <br><br><a rel=3D"nofollow" target=3D"_=
blank" href=3D"http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/woolley_gecco14.pdf">http://e=
plex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/woolley_gecco14.pdf</a><br><br>This paper discloses =
some interesting results that show that in the hard maze domain, a human in=
 collaboration with novelty search (and an objective optimization function)=
 can actually do better than novelty search alone, fitness alone, human+obj=
ective optimization alone, and more.  By better I don't just mean in t=
erms of number of evaluations, but even (surprisingly) in total clock time.=
  <br><br>The main insight is that humans and novelty search (NS) are =
complementary forces.  NS does a great job of collecting potential ste=
pping stones from the search space, but humans are extremely sensitive to c=
ertain very delicate key features (that may be difficult to formalize even =
in a behavior characterization).  Thus if NS does most of the work but=
 humans are allowed to interleave a few very critical key decisions, the co=
llaboration makes a good team.  <br><br>I think of NS in this context =
as a sort of substitute for all the other users on Picbreeder when you are =
instead alone by yourself with only a computer to help you.  Ideally, =
you'd have hundreds of people scavenging the search space and presenting yo=
u with every interesting stepping stone that they can, but short of that, N=
S can play a similar role.<br><br>One other aspect of this study that I thi=
nk is particularly interesting is the insight that we do not necessarily "h=
elp" people simply by trying to figure out where they want to go and then a=
utomating the search towards that inferred objective.  I think a lot o=
f people have the intuition that it would be cool if interactive evolution =
could figure out the kinds of things you like and then sort of accelerate i=
tself by choosing the stuff you would have chosen, but much faster.  H=
owever, what this study shows is that we humans have a much more pressing p=
roblem than simply wishing to be a faster version of ourselves - rather, we=
 need to pushed out of our comfort zone from time to time to help us see th=
e possibilities we never imagined.  Otherwise we, just like an objecti=
ve search, may tend to stagnate.  NS can provide that push.<br><br>Bes=
t,<br><br>ken</p>

    </div>
     

    

</div>
